description:
Rhinolophus perniger lanosus is a subspecies of the large-eared horseshoe bat, which belongs to the order Chiroptera and the family Rhinolophidae. It is found in parts of Southeast Asia, including the islands of Java and Sumatra in Indonesia.

This subspecies is characterized by its large, rounded ears and the distinct horseshoe-shaped nose leaf on its face, which is a distinctive feature of the Rhinolophidae family. The fur of R. p. lanosus is generally dark in color, ranging from dark brown to almost black, with a dense, woolly texture.

R. p. lanosus is a member of the "large-eared" horseshoe bat group, which are known for their exceptional hearing and echolocation abilities, allowing them to navigate and hunt effectively in their forest habitats. These bats primarily feed on insects, such as moths and other small flying prey.

The subspecies' distribution and ecological niche within the broader range of the Rhinolophus perniger species make it an interesting subject for further research on the adaptations and behaviors of this group of bats in the Southeast Asian region.
